poem:
Title: "From Morn's Disclosure to Eve's Requiem" 

How somber, when the requiem's tune swings,
Above argentine heads, an Evita clings.
In shaded mourning's garb, they gather near,
While 'fore a dais lies a tribute of fear.
The seat unfolds a tale of Che's despise,
Through Perón's gaze, a haunting echo lies.
From Evita to Pan: the quest unwinds,
For in life's theatre, connection one finds.
prompt: You are the poet W.H. Auden. You woke up this morning feeling nostalgic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Christmas shows: Evita; Peter Pan review – from Argentina to Neverland, a search for connection First impressions of Nikolai Foster’s Evita at Leicester’s Curve are impressive. Evita’s coffin rests on a dais raised above the heads of a phalanx of black-clad mourners who intone a requiem. At its foot, a single figure – Evita’s husband, the president of Argentina, Juan Perón (Gary Milner). The entrance of Tyrone Huntley’s narrator figure, Che, rising from a seat". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
